DataElement.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Excision Personal Medical History Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced involving the surgical resection of a non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina or a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Excision Personal Medical History
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced involving the surgical resection of a non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina or a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ Lobular Breast Carcinoma In Situ Excision
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.:A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

Property.preferredDefinition: an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
